Trump pleads not guilty to 34 felony counts
READ: Trump indictment related to hush money payment
Russian authorities detain suspect over St. Petersburg cafe blast
Hundreds of millions at risk from Chinese shopping app malware
The haunting Masters meltdown that changed Rory McIlroy's career
item.content:encoded: Slumped on his club, head buried in his arm, Rory McIlroy looked on the verge of tears.

item.title: The most beautiful sections of China's Great Wall
item.content:encoded: Having lived in Beijing for almost 12 years, I've had plenty of time to travel widely in China.

item.title: Look of the Week: Blackpink headline Coachella in Korean hanboks
item.content:encoded: Bringing the second day of this year's Coachella to a close, K-Pop girl group Blackpink made history Saturday night when they became the first Asian act to ever headline the festival. To a crowd of, reportedly, over 125,000 people, Jennie, Jisoo, Lisa and Rosé used the ground-breaking moment to pay homage to Korean heritage by arriving onstage in hanboks: a traditional type of dress.

item.title: Scientists film deepest ever fish on seabed off Japan
item.content:encoded: Cruising at a depth of 8,336 meters (over 27,000 feet) just above the seabed, a young snailfish has become the deepest fish ever filmed by scientists during a probe into the abyss of the northern Pacific Ocean.

item.title: Still haven't filed your taxes? Here's what you need to know
item.content:encoded: So far this tax season, the IRS has received more than 90 million income tax returns for 2022.

item.title: Markets digest bank earnings after recent turmoil
Retail spending fell in March as consumers pull back
item.content:encoded: Spending at US retailers fell in March as consumers pulled back amid recessionary fears fueled by the banking crisis.

item.title: Analysis: Fox News is about to enter the true No Spin Zone
item.content:encoded: This is it.

item.title: Silicon Valley Bank collapse renews calls to address disparities impacting entrepreneurs of color
item.content:encoded: When customers at Silicon Valley Bank rushed to withdraw billions of dollars last month, venture capitalist Arlan Hamilton stepped in to help some of the founders of color who panicked about losing access to payroll funds.

item.title: 'I was up to my waist down a hippo's throat.' He survived, and here's his advice
item.content:encoded: Paul Templer was living his best life.

item.title: See the world's deepest fish
item.content:encoded: Scientists captured the unknown snailfish species at a depth of more than 27,000 feet, as part of an expedition in trenches off Japan.

item.title: Michael Jordan's 1998 NBA Finals sneakers sell for a record $2.2 million
item.content:encoded:
In 1998, Michael Jordan laced up a pair of his iconic black and red Air Jordan 13s to bring home a Bulls victory during Game 2 of his final NBA championship — and now they are the most expensive sneakers ever to sell at auction.
The game-winning sneakers sold for $2.2 million at Sotheby's in New York on Tuesday, smashing the sneaker auction record of $1.47 million, set in 2021 by a pair of Nike Air Ships that Jordan wore earlier in his career.

item.title: How Playboy cut ties with Hugh Hefner to create a post-MeToo brand
item.content:encoded: Hugh Hefner launched Playboy Magazine 70 years ago this year. The first issue included a nude photograph of Marilyn Monroe, which he had purchased and published without her knowledge or consent.

item.title: They bought an abandoned 'ghost house' in the Japanese countryside
item.content:encoded: He'd spent years backpacking around the world, and Japanese traveler Daisuke Kajiyama was finally ready to return home to pursue his long-held dream of opening up a guesthouse.

item.title: Here's the real reason to turn on airplane mode when you fly
item.content:encoded: We all know the routine by heart: "Please ensure your seats are in the upright position, tray tables stowed, window shades are up, laptops are stored in the overhead bins and electronic devices are set to flight mode."

item.title: 'A definitive backslide.' Inside fashion's worrying runway trend
item.content:encoded: Now that the Fall-Winter 2023 catwalks have been disassembled, it's clear one trend was more pervasive than any collective penchant for ruffles, pleated skirts or tailored coats.

item.title: The $500 billion beauty industry's 'green' ambitions are a patchwork at best. And they're falling short
item.content:encoded: The escalating climate crisis is shifting many people's purchasing patterns and this extends to the $500 billion dollar global beauty industry which is grappling with a range of sustainability challenges across product manufacturing, packaging and disposal.

item.title: What to know about the Trump indictment on the eve of his court appearance
Haberman reveals why Trump attacked judge and his family in speech
item.content:encoded: CNN political contributor Maggie Haberman explains the reasoning behind Donald Trump's attacks on the judge and his family during a speech at his Mar-a-Lago resort after he was arraigned on felony charges.

item.title: Syrian refugee elected mayor of German town, years after fleeing war
item.content:encoded: A Syrian who arrived in Germany as a refugee in 2015 has won a mayoral election in the southwestern German state of Baden-Württemberg.

item.title: Kwame Brathwaite, photographer of 'Black is Beautiful' movement, dies at 85
item.content:encoded: Kwame Brathwaite, the pioneering activist and photographer whose work helped define the aesthetics of the "Black is Beautiful" movement of the 1960s and beyond, died on April 1, aged 85.

item.title: Britain's pound is beating every other major currency this year
item.content:encoded: The British pound crashed to a record low last fall as investors rebelled against budget plans by former Prime Minister Liz Truss. Now, it's enjoying a comeback.

item.title: The four astronauts NASA picked for the first crewed moon mission in 50 years
item.content:encoded: Astronauts who will helm the first crewed moon mission in five decades were revealed on Monday, queuing up the quartet to begin training for the historic Artemis II lunar flyby that is set to take off in November 2024.

item.title: These are the animals people most want to see photographed
item.content:encoded: Originally a term used by trophy hunters in Africa, the "Big Five" described the animals most challenging to shoot and kill: the lion, elephant, leopard, rhino, and buffalo. Nowadays, it is more loosely used to refer to some of Africa's largest and most iconic animals.

item.title: 2023 March Madness: Will UConn or San Diego State triumph in the national championship game that 'means everything?'
item.content:encoded: After a March Madness filled with twists and surprises -- all four No. 1 seeds failed to reach the Elite Eight for the first ever time in NCAA men's basketball tournament history -- it is time for the grand finale as UConn faces San Diego State on Monday for the title.

item.title: Beijing promised to 'fight back' over Taiwan leader's US visit. But this time it has more to lose
item.content:encoded: An anticipated meeting between Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen and US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy in California this week has sparked concerns of a repeat of the pressure campaign China launched last year when then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Taipei.

item.title: Micron Technology: China probes US chip maker for cybersecurity risks as tech tension escalates
item.content:encoded: China has launched a cybersecurity probe into Micron Technology, one of America's largest memory chip makers, in apparent retaliation after US allies in Asia and Europe announced new restrictions on the sale of key technology to Beijing.

item.title: What OPEC's surprise oil cut means for gas prices
item.content:encoded: OPEC and its allies' surprise move to slash oil production will soon be felt at US gas pumps.

item.title: Video shows moment of deadly explosion at cafe in Russia
item.content:encoded: A well-known Russian military blogger, Vladlen Tatarsky, was killed in an explosion at a cafe in St. Petersburg, authorities said. CNN's Matthew Chance reports.

item.title: Dogecoin jumps after Elon Musk replaces Twitter bird with Shiba Inu
item.content:encoded: Twitter's traditional bird icon was booted and replaced with an image of a Shiba Inu, an apparent nod to dogecoin, the joke cryptocurrency that CEO Elon Musk is being sued over.

item.title: Musk's Twitter promised a purge of blue check marks. Instead he singled out the New York Times
item.content:encoded: Some VIP Twitter users woke up on Saturday expecting to have lost their coveted blue verification check marks in a previously announced purge by Elon Musk. Instead, Twitter appeared to target a single account from a major publication Musk dislikes and changed the language on its site in a way that obscures why users are verified.

item.title: A new approach to a Covid-19 nasal vaccine shows early promise
item.content:encoded: Scientists in Germany say they've been able to make a nasal vaccine that can shut down a Covid-19 infection in the nose and throat, where the virus gets its first foothold in the body.

item.title: Angel Reese defends gesture directed towards Caitlin Clark after LSU national title win; calls out double standard after being 'unapologetically' her
item.content:encoded: LSU star Angel Reese defended the gesture she aimed at Iowa Hawkeyes' Caitlin Clark near the end of the Tigers' first NCAA women's basketball national championship victory on Sunday, saying "I don't take disrespect lightly."

item.title: Study finds slightly higher risk of autism diagnosis in areas with more lithium in drinking water, but experts say more research is needed
item.content:encoded: A new study found a moderately higher risk of autism spectrum disorder in children born to pregnant people exposed to tap water with higher levels of lithium, but experts caution that this association does not show a direct link between the two.

item.title: Israeli military veterans, a backbone of protest movement, vow to keep demonstrating
item.content:encoded: In a sea of Israeli flags, Yiftach Golov holds one that looks a little different.

item.title: Shania Twain calls for equal pay and more diversity in country music
item.content:encoded: Shania Twian is standing up for others in country music.

item.title: What pet cemeteries reveal about being human
item.content:encoded: Why do we bury our departed loved ones in a cemetery? A primary purpose is to provide survivors with an opportunity to grieve and gain a sense of closure. The cemetery is a place for the living as much as it is a place for the dead.

item.title: Erdogan's political fate may be determined by Turkey's Kurds
item.content:encoded: Turkey's persecuted pro-Kurdish party has emerged as a kingmaker in the country's upcoming election, playing a decisive role that may just tip the balance enough to unseat two-decade ruler Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

item.title: Chelsea searches for new manager as Premier League breaks record for most sackings in a single season
item.content:encoded: It was just six months ago that Graham Potter was deemed the man to usher in a fresh, exciting era at Chelsea.

item.title: Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich appeals against arrest, Russian state media says
Suspected Chinese spy balloon was able to transmit information back to Beijing
item.content:encoded: The suspected Chinese spy balloon that transited the US earlier this year was able to capture imagery and collect some signals intelligence from US military sites, a source familiar with the matter tells CNN.

item.title: This boiled bag of offal is banned in the US. In Scotland it's a fine-dining treat
item.content:encoded: Anthony Bourdain loved haggis. But even the late, great American chef, writer and television host recognized that Scotland's national dish, with its "sinister sheep parts" wrapped in a shroud of mystery and half-invented history, could be a hard sell.

item.title: HSBC's top execs face tense shareholders calling for a breakup
item.content:encoded: HSBC's top brass defended their strategy Monday to frustrated shareholders in the lender's largest market, as Europe's biggest bank continued to face calls to be split up.

item.title: Giving Marjorie Taylor Greene a platform isn't good for America
item.content:encoded: Last year, GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia spoke at a white nationalist event organized by Holocaust denier Nick Fuentes that caused Republican leaders to denounce her.

item.title: Teenage swimmer breaks two world records in four days
item.content:encoded: Sixteen-year-old Summer McIntosh broke the world record for the 400m individual medley at the Canadian swimming trials on Saturday -- just days after breaking the world record for the 400m freestyle.

item.title: 'Scary, cold, hungry and lonely': Volunteer soldier shares experience on front line
item.content:encoded: A young volunteer soldier, Akula, who signed up for the war at the beginning of the Russian invasion is now dealing with the trauma of war. He spoke to CNN's David McKenzie about his time on the front lines and how it has affected his mental health.

item.title: French minister under fire for Playboy magazine cover
item.content:encoded: French government minister Marlene Schiappa has come under fire from members of her own party after appearing on the front cover of Playboy magazine.

item.title: China Renaissance suspends trading, delays results after founder's disappearance
item.content:encoded: China Renaissance, a top dealmaker in the country's tech industry, said it would suspend trading of its shares and delay the release of its annual results because it still can't get in touch with its founder.

item.title: CEOs are tired of being held responsible for gun regulation
item.content:encoded: Americans have grown used to corporate executives treading the well-worn paths of the Northeast corridor to convene alongside elected officials in Washington, DC, and discuss geopolitics, policy and all that's in-between.

item.title: Some fans whistle as Lionel Messi's name is announced as Paris Saint-Germain's season hits new low
item.content:encoded: Paris Saint-Germain's miserable season went from bad to worse on Sunday as the team suffered a second straight home defeat with a 1-0 loss to Lyon.

item.title: Finland's Prime Minister Sanna Marin concedes election
item.content:encoded: Finland's left-wing Prime Minister Sanna Marin conceded defeat on Sunday in the Nordic country's parliamentary election as the opposition right-wing National Coalition Party (NCP) claimed victory in a tightly fought contest.

item.title: Video shows moment man throws yogurt on two women in Iran
item.content:encoded: Video shows an incident at a store in the Iranian city of Shandiz where a man approached two unveiled women before proceeding to grab a tub of yogurt from the store and throw it, hitting both women in the head. The video then appears to show a male staff member removing the suspect from the store. CNN is not able to verify what was said immediately before the confrontation.

item.title: Why did Finland's PM lose? Reporter explains the key issue voters cared about
item.content:encoded: Finland's left-wing Prime Minister Sanna Marin conceded defeat in the country's parliamentary election as the opposition right-wing National Coalition Party claimed victory in a tightly fought contest. CNN's Laila Harrak spoke with New York Times' Chief Diplomatic Correspondent Steven Erlanger to discuss how the popular politician lost the election.

item.title: Emma Heming Willis shares family photos as daughter Mabel turns 11
item.content:encoded: Bruce Willis' wife, Emma Heming Willis, has celebrated their elder daughter's birthday with a trip down memory lane.

item.title: Lawmaker speaks out about his struggle with depression
item.content:encoded: Sen. John Fetterman (D-PA) spoke to CBS about battling with depression after winning a tight election.

item.title: Man rides out tornado inside van. See the footage
item.content:encoded: Cody Coombes recounts riding out a tornado in Little Rock, Arkansas, inside his pest control van. The National Weather Service reported that an EF-3 tornado had roared through Pulaski and Lonoke counties with estimated peak winds of 165 mph, killing one person in North Little Rock and four people in Wynne.

item.title: See 'Star Wars' legend react to Acosta's Darth Vader impression
item.content:encoded: Actor Mark Hamill joins CNN's Jim Acosta to discuss his thoughts about a potential spinoff series based around his legendary "Star Wars" character Luke Skywalker.

item.title: Palestinian taxi driver recounts surviving attack by right-wing protesters
item.content:encoded: A Palestinian taxi driver describes surviving a violent attack by a right-wing mob in Jerusalem earlier this week as Israel continues to see protests against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's judicial overhaul spread. CNN's Nic Robertson reports.

item.title: A snowboarder got buried upside down in snow. See skier's quick reaction.
item.content:encoded: Skier Francis Zuber sprang into action when he noticed a snowboarder had become trapped upside down in a tree well. Zuber, whose reaction has been applauded as a textbook example of what to do in such a situation, urged others to take up rescue courses.

item.title: Relaxed entry rules make it easier than ever to visit this stunning Asian nation
item.content:encoded: Due to its remoteness and short summer season, Mongolia has long been a destination overlooked by travelers.

item.title: Scientists identify secret ingredient in Leonardo da Vinci paintings
item.content:encoded: "Old Masters" such as Leonardo da Vinci, Sandro Botticelli and Rembrandt may have used proteins, especially egg yolk, in their oil paintings, according to a new study.

item.title: The surreal facades of America's strip clubs
item.content:encoded: Some people travel the world in search of adventure, while others seek out natural wonders, cultural landmarks or culinary experiences. But French photographer François Prost was looking for something altogether different during his recent road trip across America: strip clubs.

item.title: Nelly Cheboi, who creates computer labs for Kenyan schoolchildren, is CNN's Hero of the Year
item.content:encoded: Celebrities and musicians are coming together tonight to honor everyday people making the world a better place.

item.title: CNN Heroes: Sharing the Spotlight
These were the best and worst places for air quality in 2021, new report shows
item.content:encoded: Air pollution spiked to unhealthy levels around the world in 2021, according to a new report.

item.title: Not only is Lake Powell's water level plummeting because of drought, its total capacity is shrinking, too
item.content:encoded: Lake Powell, the second-largest human-made reservoir in the US, has lost nearly 7% of its potential storage capacity since 1963, when Glen Canyon Dam was built, a new report shows.

item.title: Big-box stores could help slash emissions and save millions by putting solar panels on roofs. Why aren't more of them doing it?
item.content:encoded: As the US attempts to wean itself off its heavy reliance on fossil fuels and shift to cleaner energy sources, many experts are eyeing a promising solution: your neighborhood big-box stores and shopping malls.

item.title: Sign up to our newsletter for a weekly roundup of travel news
Donate now to a Top 10 CNN Hero
item.content:encoded: Anderson Cooper explains how you can easily donate to any of the 2021 Top 10 CNN Heroes.
